tutorial.title: Class Test Results
tutorial.descriptionContent: Calculate some statistics from a class' test results.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's practice our skills by using variables to analyze and display the latest test grades of a small class of students.

First, take a look at the existing HTML and CSS code we'll work with in this project. When you run the code you'll get a sense of the page layout.

1. Review the HTML in `index.html` - the "class test results" container is already structured.
2. Review the CSS in`style.css` - all of the styling needed for the project has been provided.
3. Finally, we've added some code in `script.js` to connect your JavaScript code to the HTML. We'll add more of this at the end of the project.

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Now, let's create variables for our project.

We need variables to hold information about the students' test results. Let's create all of the variables and set their values.

Note that you'll need to code everything above the starter code.

1. Above `listItemArray`, create the variable `maxPoints` and set the value to `120`.
2. Create the variable `passingPoints` and set the value to `70`.
3. Create the variable `samPoints` and set the value to `84`.
4. Create the variable `alexPoints` and set the value to `45`. We will be updating this value later.
5. Create the variable `jessiePoints` and set the value to `99`.
6. Create the variable `didAlexPass` and set the value to `false`. We will be updating this value later.

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Remember to use `const` or 'let', depending on if the variable is constant or not, followed by the variable name and then assign a value to it by using the assign operator `=`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have declared most of the variables we'll need, let's display Sam's results.

1. Create the variable `samPointsDisplay` and set the value to `"Sam earned " + samPoints + " points out of " + maxPoints;`.
2. Print `samPointsDisplay` to the console. The output should look like this:

```
Sam earned 84 points out of 120
```

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: 1. Make sure to use `console.log(samPointsDisplay)` to view Sam's information.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we've displayed Sam's points, let's display Alex and Jessie's points using the same approach. We can copy Sam's concatenated display message and adapt it to Alex and Jessie's test results.

1. Create the variable `alexPointsDisplay`.
2. Create the variable `jessiePointsDisplay`.
3. Print Alex's points to the console.
4. Print Jessie's points to the console. The output of these console logs should look like this:

```
Alex earned 45 points out of 120
Jessie earned 99 points out of 120
```

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have points displayed for all three students, let's calculate Sam's score percentage and display that information as well.

1. Create the variable `samPercentage` and set the value to `(samPoints/maxPoints)*100`
2. Create the variable `samPercentDisplay`
3. Print Sam's percentage to the console, which should look like this:

```
Sam scored 70%.
```

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Make sure that `const samPercentage= (samPoints/maxPoints)*100`.
2. Make sure that the `samPercentDisplay` stores `"Sam scored " + samPercentage + "%."`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have Sam's percentage displayed, let's display Alex and Jessie's percentages using the same structure we used for Sam. We can copy Sam's concatenated display message and adapt it to Alex and Jessie's information.

1. Using code from Sam's percentage, create variables for Alex and Jessie to save their percentages.
2. Print Alex's percentage to the console.
3. Print Jessie's percentage to the console. The output of these two console logs should look like this:

```
Alex scored 37.5%.
Jessie scored 82.5%.
```

files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have points and percentages displayed for all three students, let's calculate Sam's missed points.

1. Create the variable `samMissedPoints` and set the value to be the difference between `maxPoints` and `samPoints`.

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: 1. Make sure that `const samMissedPoints = maxPoints - samPoints`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have the missed points calculated for Sam, let's use the same structure to calculate Alex and Jessie's missed points. We can copy the code from Sam's missed points and adapt it for Alex and Jessie.

1. Using code from Sam's missed points, create the variables `alexMissedPoints` and `jessieMissedPoints` to store Alex and Jessie's missed points.

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have missed points calculated for all three students, let's use string and variable concatenation to display Sam's missed points.

1. Create the variable `samMissedPointsDisplay` to store the display message. 
2. Print Sam's missed points to the console, which should look like this:

```
Sam missed 36 point(s).
```

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: 1. Make sure that `const samMissedPointsDisplay` stores  `"Sam missed " + samMissedPoints + " point(s)."`

lessons.title: Alex and Jessie's Missed Points Display

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have displayed the missed points for Sam, let's use the same structure to display Alex and Jessie's missed points. We can copy the code from Sam's missed points display and adapt it for Alex and Jessie.

1. Using code from Sam's missed points display, create variables to store Alex and Jessie's missed points display message.
2. Print Alex and Jessie's missed points message to the console, which should look like the following:

```
Alex missed 75 point(s).
Jessie missed 21 point(s).
```

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have the percentages and missed points calculated and displayed for all three students, let's find the average points and average percentage of the entire class.

1. Create the variable `classAveragePoints` and set the value to the sum of all three students' points divided by three.
2. Create the variable `classAveragePercent` and set the value to `classAveragePoints` divided by `maxPoints`, multiplied by `100`.

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Make sure that `classAveragePoints` stores `(samPoints+alexPoints+jessiePoints)/3`.
2. Make sure that `classAveragePercent`  stores `(classAveragePoints/maxPoints)*100`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have the average points and percentage of the class, let's display the information. We will be using a built-in method, `.toFixed(2)`, which formats numbers to two decimal places.

1. Create the variable `classAvgDisplay` by joining strings to `classAveragePoints` and `classAveragePercent.toFixed(2)`.
2.  Display the`classAvgDisplay` variable, which should look like:

```
The class average was 76 points or 63.33%.
```

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Make sure that `classAvgDisplay` stores:
```JS
"The class average was "+ classAveragePoints + " points or " + classAveragePercent.toFixed(2) + "%."
```

executableContent.instructions:
Alex was the only student who didn't pass the test. They did some extra work and are now passing. Let's update Alex's information to reflect their new score.

1. Update Alex's points to `75`.
2. Right now, `didAlexPass` is set to `false`. Update it to `true` by assigning it its negated value like `!didAlexPass`.

files.name: script.js
index.html
files.content: Class Test Results

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Make sure that `alexPoints = 75`.
2. Make sure that `didAlexPass = !didAlexPass`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that Alex's score has been updated, let's create and display a new message with Alex's new score in the console log. After this lesson, we'll display the messages on the webpage.

1. Create the variable `alexPointsUpdated` to store the new message. Code the message by joining strings with the values of `alexPoints` and `maxPoints`. 
2. Display `alexPointsUpdated`. The message should look like this:

```
Alex failed initially but did extra credit. Their new score is 75 out of 120
```
